citation.article-title: Zoogloea oryzae sp. nov., a nitrogen-fixing bacterium isolated from rice paddy soil, and reclassification of the strain ATCC 19623 as Crabtreella saccharophila gen. nov., sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Crabtreella saccharophila sp. nov.
Crabtreella saccharophila (sacc.ha.ro.phi′la. Gr. n. saccharon sugar; Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. fem. adj. saccharophila sugar-loving).
Displays the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Cells grow in CY medium (5·0 g casitone and 1·0 g yeast extract).
The optimum pH for growth is 7·0–7·5 with no growth at pH 4·5 or 9·6.
The optimum temperature is 28–30 °C, with slow growth at 10 °C and no growth at 45 °C.
H2S is produced in a peptone-cysteine-sulfated medium.
Hydrolyses tyrosine agar and brown pigment appears.

Utilizes acetate, pyruvate, malate, fumarate, oxalacetate, asparagine, aspartate, glutamate, citrulline, ornithine, arginine, histidine, tyrosine, ammonia, n-propanol, ethanol, n-butanol and ethanol, but not citrate, benzoate or m-toluate.
Acid is formed oxidatively from arabinose, ethanol, rhamnose, ribose, xylose, fructose, glucose, glycerol, mannitol and sucrose, but no acid is formed from starch or inulin.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite and nitrogen gas.
The DNA G+C content is 65·3 mol%.
